title: How do we know what color dinosaurs were? - Len Bloch

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated age of the microraptor, a carnivorous four-winged dinosaur?
What is the main reason for the shimmering black coloration of the microraptor?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of a single pigment

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of hollow nanostructures called melanosomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of melanosomes in bird feathers?

options.label: C
options.text: To form hollow nanostructures that can shine in all the colors of the rainbow

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary pigment responsible for the coloration of bird feathers?
What is the wavelength of red light?
What is the size of melanosomes that give off green light?
What is the primary factor that determines the color of feathers?

options.label: A
options.text: The size and arrangement of melanosomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the similarity between the melanosomes of the microraptor and those of modern birds?

options.label: B
options.text: They are similar but not identical

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely color of the microraptor's feathers based on the size and arrangement of its melanosomes?
What is the implication of the discovery of melanosomes in dinosaur fossils for the accuracy of certain films and representations of dinosaurs?

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that dinosaurs were more colorful than previously thought

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that dinosaurs had feathers

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that dinosaurs were less colorful than previously thought

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Water vapor molecules stick to the edges of the snowflake and grow inwards

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of writing fiction?

options.label: B
options.text: To engage the reader's senses and create a momentary illusion that they are living in the world of the story

title: When to use "me", "myself" and "I" - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between the subject and object in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: The subject is the word that is acted upon, while the object is the actor.

options.label: B
options.text: The subject is the actor, while the object is the word that is acted upon.

options.label: C
options.text: The subject is the word that performs an action, while the object is the word that receives the action.

options.label: D
options.text: The subject is the word that receives an action, while the object is the word that performs the action.

options.label: B
options.text: It is used as a reflexive pronoun.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used as an intensive pronoun.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used as a subject pronoun.

options.text: When it is the object of a sentence whose subject is "I."

options.label: C
options.text: When it is used to add emphasis to a sentence.

options.label: D
options.text: When it is used in a sentence with multiple subjects.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between "I" and "me" in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: "I" is used as an object pronoun, while "me" is used as a subject pronoun.

options.label: B
options.text: "I" is used as a subject pronoun, while "me" is used as an object pronoun.

options.label: C
options.text: "I" is used as a reflexive pronoun, while "me" is used as an intensive pronoun.

options.label: D
options.text: "I" is used as an intensive pronoun, while "me" is used as a reflexive pronoun.

options.label: D
options.text: English, Latin, and many other languages

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the subject of the sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify the object of the sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the correct usage of "I," "me," and "myself."

options.label: D
options.text: To add emphasis to the sentence.

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: It is used when the subject of the sentence is "they."

options.label: D
options.text: It is used when the subject of the sentence is "we."

options.label: A
options.text: The first sentence uses "myself" as an object pronoun, while the second sentence uses "myself" as a subject pronoun.

options.label: B
options.text: The first sentence uses "myself" as a reflexive pronoun, while the second sentence uses "myself" as an intensive pronoun.

options.label: C
options.text: The first sentence uses "myself" to add emphasis, while the second sentence uses "myself" as a reflexive pronoun.

options.label: D
options.text: The first sentence uses "myself" as an intensive pronoun, while the second sentence uses "myself" as a reflexive pronoun.
